articles.headline: Iraqis Fail to Agree on Provincial Election Law
articles.snippet: The failure to reach a deal before Parliament’s recess left the fate of provincial elections in doubt.
articles.abstract: The failure to reach a deal before Parliament’s recess left the fate of provincial elections in doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraqi lawmakers adjourned for the summer on Wednesday without passing a crucial election law that many here hoped would solidify the recent, still fragile gains in security. The failure seemed likely to mean the postponement of provincial elections, originally set for October, until next year  polling seen as vital to reconciling the deep-seated tensions among Iraq’s political and sectarian groups.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Monsanto Looks to Sell Dairy Hormone Business
articles.snippet: The move comes as more retailers, saying they are responding to consumer demand, are selling dairy products from cows not treated with the artificial hormone.
articles.abstract: The move comes as more retailers, saying they are responding to consumer demand, are selling dairy products from cows not treated with the artificial hormone.
articles.lead_paragraph: After struggling to gain consumer acceptance, Monsanto on Wednesday announced that it would try to sell its business of producing an artificial growth hormone for dairy cows. The company will focus instead on its thriving business of selling seeds and developing ways to improve crops.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Speak Up, a Computer Is Listening
articles.snippet: Ever since “Star Trek,” we’ve dreamed of being able to give our computers spoken orders. NaturallySpeaking 10, available Thursday, takes some baby steps in the right direction.
articles.abstract: Ever since “Star Trek,” we’ve dreamed of being able to give our computers spoken orders. NaturallySpeaking 10, available Thursday, takes some baby steps in the right direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the high-tech fantasies that sci-fi movies tantalize their escapist audiences with, surely that bit about giving your computer spoken orders is one of the most alluring. Ever since “Star Trek,” we’ve dreamed of being able to say, “Computer, display all known sources of dilithium crystals in the Kraxon Nebula!”

articles.headline: 500: Deadly U.S. Milestone in Afghan War
articles.snippet: With U.S. troops at record levels and the violent threat from the Taliban expanding, the conflict in Afghanistan is roaring back into public view.
articles.abstract: With U.S. troops at record levels and the violent threat from the Taliban expanding, the conflict in Afghanistan is roaring back into public view.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long after Staff Sgt. Matthew D. Blaskowski was killed by a sniper’s bullet last Sept. 23 in eastern Afghanistan, his mother received an e-mail message with a link to a video on the Internet. A television reporter happened to have been filming a story at Sergeant Blaskowski’s small mountain outpost when it came under fire and the sergeant was shot.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Tempest for a Bank That Bet on Risky Loans
articles.snippet: Easy money has created enormous problems at Bank United, Florida’s biggest regional bank.
articles.abstract: Easy money has created enormous problems at Bank United, Florida’s biggest regional bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  A cheerful sign outside the glistening offices of Bank United beckons consumers to tap into “Mortgage-ade.” Another promises a “59 Minute Mortgage.”

articles.headline: In Retail Sales, More Signs of a Slowdown
articles.snippet: Stocks fell sharply as sales reports revealed a country that is ratcheting back its spending habits and abandoning mid-tier and discount shopping mall mainstays.
articles.abstract: Stocks fell sharply as sales reports revealed a country that is ratcheting back its spending habits and abandoning mid-tier and discount shopping mall mainstays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans sought out more bargains and cheaper goods in July, leaving the nation’s retailers bracing for a painful back-to-school shopping season and investors on Wall Street once again worried about the outlook for the economy.

articles.headline: Truck Sale Slump Weighs on Toyota
articles.snippet: The automaker said that its worldwide net income for the quarter fell 28 percent, hurt by slumping sales of its Tundra pickup truck and S.U.V.’s made and sold in North America.
articles.abstract: The automaker said that its worldwide net income for the quarter fell 28 percent, hurt by slumping sales of its Tundra pickup truck and S.U.V.’s made and sold in North America.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Even Toyota Motor, Japan’s largest automaker, felt the pain in the first quarter from the collapsing market for big pickups and sport utility vehicles in the United States.
